flashcards.definition: The highest class of international auto racing for single-seater formula racing cars.
An international motor racing event, part of the F1 World Championship.
Italian word for a motor racing team, commonly associated with Ferrari.
A stop made by a car in the pit lane during a race for new tires, repairs, or adjustments.
An adjustable rear wing flap allowing drivers to gain speed on designated straight sections.
The starting position on the grid for the driver who set the fastest time in qualifying.
Flag waved to signal the end of a race or session.
A car that limits the speed of competing cars on the track during a hazard.
The team that designs and builds the car, competing for a championship.
Awarded to the driver who accumulates the most points over the season.
Awarded to the team (constructor) that accumulates the most points over the season.
The top three finishing positions in a race.
The key link between a driver and the team, managing car setup and strategy.
The pre-planned approach for a race, including pit stop timing and tire choices.
The specific type of rubber used for a tire, affecting grip and durability.
The first lap completed after leaving the pit lane.
The lap a driver takes to enter the pit lane.
A secure area where cars are kept after qualifying and the race under strict conditions.
Officials appointed to oversee a race and enforce the rules, issuing penalties.
A punishment applied to a driver or team for breaking the rules.
The starting positions on the track for the race, determined by qualifying.
The lap drivers complete before the start to warm up tires and get into grid position.
A sequence of tight corners, typically in alternate directions, designed to slow cars down.
The geometric midpoint of a corner, closest to the inside of the turn.
When the front tires lose grip, causing the car to turn less sharply than intended.
When the rear tires lose grip, causing the car to turn more sharply than intended (tail spins out).
An aerodynamic component at the rear of the car that generates downforce.
A protective barrier around the cockpit designed to protect the driver's head.
The entire powertrain including the engine, turbo, and energy recovery systems.
System that recovers energy for deployment as extra power.
The manager responsible for the overall operation and performance of an F1 team.
